name: Plano Convex
description: OptiCloud's plano-convex lenses have a positive focal length and can be used to focus collimated light, to collimate a point source, or reduce the divergence angle of a diverging source.
author: admin

name: Bi Convex
description: Opticloud's bi-convex lenses are popular for many finite imaging applications. Bi-convex lenses are most suitable where the object and image are on opposite sides of the lens and the ratio of the image and object distances (conjugate ratio) is between 0.2 and 5.
author: admin

name: Plano Concave
description: Plano-concave lenses diverge a collimated beam from a virtual focus and are commonly used in Galilean-type beam expanders. Given their negative focal length and negative spherical aberration, plano-concave lenses can be used to balance out aberrations of other lenses in the system.
author: admin

name: Bi Concave
description: Bi-concave lenses have a negative focal length and are best used to diverge a converging beam. Bi-concave lenses can diverge a collimated beam to a virtual focus and are commonly used in Galilean-type beam expanders.
author: admin

name: Positive Meniscus
description: Positive meniscus lenses are used to decrease the focal length of another lens while maintaining the angular resolution of the optical assembly. These lenses are commonly used to achieve tighter beam focusing when paired with another positive lens.
author: admin

name: Negative Meniscus
description: Negative meniscus lenses are designed to minimize spherical aberration. These N-BK7, UV fused silica, calcium fluoride, and zinc selenide lenses consist of a convex surface and a concave surface where the concave surface has the greater radius of curvature. In combination with another lens, a negative meniscus lens will decrease the NA of the system. A negative meniscus lens is a common element in beam expanding applications
author: admin
